View times Now, Tony celebrates a life on stage and screen—sharing stories from his remarkable career, his passion for history, and his thrilling fiction debut , an epic tale of and the bloody birth of England. Hear behind-the-scenes stories from , and beyond – and have the chance to ask Tony anything, from writing his first novel at 78 to why Baldrick still gets the biggest laughs. Drawing on decades of archaeological expertise and his gift for making the past come alive, Tony will reveal the gritty reality behind the legend of in his latest work. What was life really like for ordinary people caught between Saxon kings and Viking raiders? How did political scheming in medieval courts compare to today's power struggles? This isn't just historical fiction – it’s Tony’s unique take on the real events that forged our nation. This will be a night of brilliant storytelling, big laughs, and history with a twist—all delivered by a man who always had… a cunning plan. Set in a beguiling bay on the shores of Tāpapakanga Regional Park, is a boutique music & arts festival like no other. A three-day immersive entertainment extravaganza and the greatest costume party in Aotearoa. View times Splore is a beachside celebration where music, art and community gather beneath the pōhutukawa at Tāpapakanga Regional Park. Days drift from beach swims to dance-floor joy, kids darting between artworks, and friends sharing delicious kai under the trees. As evening arrives, stages glow, costumes shimmer and strangers feel like whānau. It’s playful, warm and genuinely welcoming, a place to rest or rave, reflect or be ridiculous. Salt on your skin, music in your chest, stars overhead. Life at its brightest. Alongside the music sits a generous programme of performance, arts, ceremony and wellbeing. You’ll find dancers, circus artists and storytellers moving through the park, while workshops offer movement, meditation and craft. The whenua shapes the festival. Splore works with Ngāti Whanaunga and Ngāti Pāoa to honour Tāpapakanga, uplifting mātauranga Māori and welcoming guests with care and connection. Pōwhiri opens the gathering and the stories of this place guide the experience. Culture sits at the heart of the celebration, held with respect. Splore also leads with sustainability. Its zero-waste approach, thoughtful design and long-term environmental kaupapa are recognised here and overseas. Everyone plays their part, helping protect the land, waters and wildlife that make Tāpapakanga so special. Come with curiosity. Be open. Be part of it. Te wāhi Tāpapakanga Regional Park

2025 Two-Time PGA Tour winner Ryan Fox returns to his home course to host the 4th edition of Mānuka Phuel Chasing the Fox – the most entertaining golf event of the year. View times Chasing the Fox is New Zealand’s premier short-format golf event — where world-class golf meets unforgettable entertainment. Each December at Ryan Fox’s home course, six holes of high-energy Ambrose action transform the game into a festival of sport, music, and spectacle. This year, Fox is bringing a friend from tour to take on a one-of-a-kind field featuring top sporting teams, pro golfers, YouTube stars, and more. Every team competes not just for bragging rights, but for prizemoney to support their chosen charity. The format is simple but thrilling: professional golfers play as pairs, while celebrity teams get the advantage of three players. It’s fast, unpredictable stroke play with no handicaps — lowest score wins. And if it’s tied, the drama builds to a playoff shootout on the final hole. Fans don’t just watch — they’re part of the action. Walk the fairways alongside the players, soak in the atmosphere, and experience every shot up close. It’s golf like you’ve never seen it before. And when play reaches the legendary Party Hole, the energy hits another level — with world-renowned DJ Cyril performing live as the sun sets. From great food and drinks to live entertainment and interactive fan zones, Chasing the Fox is more than a golf event - it’s a sports entertainment festival that captures the excitement of summer in one incredible day. Te huarahi ki reira Chasing the Fox is held at Royal Auckland & Grange Golf Club in South Auckland — just a short trip from the city. description: Experience the electrifying reunion of Formula One’s most captivating driver partnership, as former team-mates, bitter-rivals and friends Mika Häkkinen and David Coulthard take to the stage. View times Join & hosted by a special guest interviewer for a night of high-octane entertainment—a conversation exploring their storied, turbulent time at the pinnacle of motorsport, the current state of play in F1, the electrifying 2025 season, and their predictions for 2026—all underscored by their endless banter. The illustrious duo drove as rivals and then most famously as teammate in to the with a partnership as brilliant and consistent as it was volatile, and hostile. Discover how, in retirement, their longstanding rivalry evolved into an enduring friendship—forged on the racetrack and strengthened through mutual respect. , renowned as the only driver ever admitted to fearing, recounts his journey—including joining at McLaren, surviving a life-threatening crash at the , and executing his iconic 300km/h overtake at the , voted by fans as the greatest overtake in motorsport history. He will also reflect on his path to winning back-to-back titles in 1998 & 1999. , regarded as one of Britain’s fastest and most consistent drivers in motorsport, will share insights from his 15-season career, from replacing at in 1994 to securing his maiden win in 1995, racing for and , and accumulating 13 Grand Prix victories, including two wins each at both the and . Together, they’ll dissect defining moments—from controversial team orders to dramatic on-track collisions—and reflect on how they brought the World Constructors Championship in 1998. Don't miss this unique chance to see these fierce rivals, close friends, and F1 legends as you’ve never seen them before. Te wāhi 101 Hobson Street, Auckland Central, Auckland, New Zealand, 1010 He tīwhiri mō te rohe Go for a lunchtime stroll down Hobson Street. In only ten minutes, you’ll be looking over the blissful sea views of the Waitematā Harbour. description: I MUST NOT SPEAK NIUEAN - is a compelling call to action. View times From the ancestral cries of Tagaloa, Fao and Huanaki to the scars of colonisation, migration and climate change. description: To celebrate the summer, the returns: Greg Horsman’s fairytale version of . View times The age-old story of the princess who pricks her finger and falls into an enchanted sleep, only to be wakened by true love, is brought to life in by Gary Harris, and Tchaikovsky’s . A touch of wizardry from Wellington’s Wētā Workshop adds to the joy and wonder, making this the for audiences of all ages. 2011 saw the premiere of this glorious production, with the making of the ballet immortalised, reality television-style, in the second series of . More than 42,000 people saw the production around New Zealand. Choreographer Greg Horsman left the Royal New Zealand Ballet in 2012 to take up a new role at Queensland Ballet, and this production has now been staged there several times to great acclaim. The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity celebrates the monumental gift of significant artworks from the collection of New York philanthropists Julian (1932–2022) and Josie Robertson (1943–2010) to the Gallery. View times The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity celebrates the monumental gift of significant artworks from the collection of New York philanthropists Julian (1932–2022) and Josie Robertson (1943–2010) to the Gallery. The donation comprises 15 works by influential modern European artists, including Pierre Bonnard, Georges Braque, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dalí, André Derain, Henri Fantin-Latour, Paul Gauguin, Fernand Léger, Henri Matisse, Piet Mondrian and Pablo Picasso. Beginning with the suggestive nude bodies of the late 19th century and ending with a monumental colour-field painting from the 1960s, The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity takes visitors on a journey through the major art movements of the modern era, including Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, Fauvism, Cubism, Surrealism, and post-war abstraction. Featuring 49 paintings, prints, drawings and sculpture, the exhibition also includes visitor favourites from the permanent collection as well as loans and other important recent acquisitions, offering a broad survey of the best of late-19th- and early-to-mid 20th-century international art. Image Credit is: (installation view), Mackelvie Trust Collection, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o Tāmaki, purchased 1991. Photography by David St George. Deeply entrenched in his own misery, Scrooge receives a visit from four ghosts who whisk him away on a journey through Christmases past, present and future. “Cassandra has delivered a war cry for the wounded wāhine within so many of us, and it is as fierce as it is vulnerable.” — Tarryn Utiger View times Tessa Ensler loves her job. She’s worked her way up from a working-class background to being a top criminal defence barrister at the top of her game: prosecuting, cross-examining and winning in the courtroom with her quick wit and intelligence. She fights to defend those pleading not guilty – including securing freedom for men accused of rape and sexual assault. Innocent until proven guilty is, after all, the bedrock of human rights. An unexpected event forces Tessa to confront the very system she has spent her life believing in and working within. This is a system where the lines of patriarchal power and burden of proof are not set up to accommodate the lived experience of sexual assault survivors. Acclaimed Olivier and Tony award-winning play, Suzie Miller’s Prima Facie, is an unforgettable story and one-woman tour de force. It is an interrogation of the legal system itself. It asks us whether there is room in that system for emotion and experience. Prima Facie was first produced by Griffin Theatre Company in May 2019 at the SBW Stables Theatre, followed by the award-winning 2022 West End premiere at the Harold Pinter Theatre, which then travelled to the Golden Theatre on Broadway in 2023. Directed by Kiwi acting royalty Michael Hurst and performed by Cassandra Woodhouse, NZ Theatre Company is honoured to bring Prima Facie to the stage. This one final Auckland performance continues the call to action that this story is demanding worldwide: “Somewhere. Sometime. Somehow. Something has to change.” “It’s sublime storytelling from a sublime storyteller, shaped by a theatre genius, and it’s for us. A gift without ego. ” — Lexie Matheson Te wāhi Te huarahi ki reira ASB Waterfront Theatre is a 17-minute walk from Waitematā Station and accessible by many bus routes, including the City Link route.

Extraordinary. Fierce. Misunderstood? You decide. This summer, dive into the world of . Bringing together cutting-edge science, indigenous perspectives, and hands-on experiences, this exhibition will show how these ancient fishes have evolved over 450 million years, and the role they play in our ocean ecosystems today. Created by the Australian Museum, this exhibition takes you beneath the surface to discover the diversity, biology, and cultural significance of one of the ocean’s most extraordinary creatures. Blending science, storytelling, and immersive design, it’s a chance to see sharks in a way you never have before. Immerse yourself in a specially designed oceanarium, come face-to-face with striking life-sized models, and get hands-on with interactive experiences that reveal the role sharks play in the health of our oceans, the threats they face today, and what we can do to protect them. description: Dive into a deep blue world teeming with life in Ngā Huhua: Abundance, an immersive exhibition celebrating the lifeforce of Te Moana-nui-a-Toi, the outer Hauraki Gulf Marine Park, just beyond Auckland’s shores. Meet the surprising and spectacular creatures that call this place home, from tohorā (whales) to honu (turtles), and explore how this ecosystem now faces new threats. Te Moana-nui-a-Toi, an area largely unknown and rarely visited by most Aucklanders, comes alive through storytelling, ocean science, mātauranga Māori, contemporary art, and the voices of tangata whenua (Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea). The exhibition reveals how both the giants and the smallest creatures play vital roles in maintaining the balance of this thriving marine world. Each year, these species gather in abundance during the seasonal upwelling of food-rich waters, a natural rhythm that has sustained life here for thousands of years. Today, that lifeforce is under pressure from climate change and human activity. Through interactives, compelling stories, and voices grounded in whakapapa, invites you to deepen your connection to the moana and feel inspired to help protect this extraordinary place. This exhibition is presented in partnership with Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea, the mana whenua (customary guardians) of Aotea Great Barrier Island, whose whakapapa (ancestry) traces back to Toi, and whose people welcomed Kupe into Rangitāwhiri (Tryphena Harbour). Exhibition is FREE with museum entry Photo: R Robinson www.depth.co.nz Te wāhi Te huarahi ki reira The Museum is a short walk from the centre of town and Waitematā station. There are also parking buildings nearby on Pakenham St East and Market Lane. He pārongo atu anō

GIVĒON is bringing DEAR BELOVED, THE TOUR to New Zealand February 2026. View times Givēon has made himself one of music’s brightest stars by bringing vivid color, depth, and soul to songs that capture the intensity of life’s twists and turns. After coming to fame via Drake’s “Chicago Freestyle,” the CA native became a force in his own right. Givēon had a whirlwind 2020 after releasing his Platinum-certified “Like I Want You” (225 million cross-platform streams in the US). He kept the momentum with “Heartbreak Anniversary,” a gauzy ballad that peaked at #16 on the Billboard Hot 100, garnered over 668 million streams, and earned 2X Platinum status. In March 2020, Givēon’s debut EP, Take Time, confirmed his evocative songwriting prowess and would be nominated for Best R&B Album at the 2021 Grammys. His fall When It’s All Said and Done EP further explored the peaks and valleys of love and, when re-packaged with its predecessor in 2021, hit #5 on the Billboard 200. After being nominated for a 2020 NAACP Image Award for Outstanding New Artist, he won BET’s 2021 Best New Artist, and his audience is growing—to the tune of over 1.7 billion streams globally. He even hit #1 on the Hot 100 in March on Justin Bieber’s “Peaches.” That hit helped him win award for Best Pop Song at the 2021 MTV VMA‘s where he was nominated for seven awards including Best New Artist, Best R&B and Best Pop Song. Drake then invited Givēon back into his world, this time for a sizzling verse on Certified Lover Boy’s “In the Bible” with Lil Durk—one of a guaranteed run of thrilling collabs to come. And at his festival debut, Lollapalooza 2021, he found a sea of voices who knew his lyrics. But success has never really been a goal—Givēon just wants to bear his soul. Yoga explores the expansiveness of what it is to be human – mind, body, spirit – in a non-competitive practice that allows individuals their own unique inquiry into the fascinating enigma of life. View times These hour-long Hatha yoga classes will include warm-up stretching, building to stronger poses, including flow balance and breath focus. Our practice and practice space is open to beginners as well as more experienced yogis aged 14 years and over. Penny Hacking completed her advanced Hatha yoga teacher training through Ashram Yoga Auckland. She has completed mental health awareness training, holds a current First Aid Certificate and is a member of the New Zealand Registered Exercise Professionals (REPs) and Yoga New Zealand, the national registration body for yoga teachers. Penny is committed to learning through yoga and working with like-minded individuals to enhance a greater balance of physical, mental and emotional well-being and resilience. Bookings are essential as we are no longer accepting over the counter purchases on the day. Condition of participation: please do not register or attend if you currently have any medical conditions, health issues (including injuries, surgeries) or illnesses that could affect your ability to undertake this class safely. “...grungy, gritty, and a bit sexy” - Stereogum “...swaggering and devastatingly cool” - NME View times Hot on the heels of announcing their highly anticipated new album Some Like It Hot, the eternally enigmatic UK post-punk darlings bar italia have also unveiled two huge New Zealand shows for this December, brought to you by Strange News Touring and Banished Music. Saturday 13th of December, the band will take the stage at Auckland’s glorious Hollywood Avondale for an all-ages show, playing Meow in Wellington on Sunday 14th December. After bursting onto the scene with two incredible albums in a single year - the brilliant Tracey Denim and the noisy niceness of The Twits - bar italia spent the next while earning a reputation as one of the best live bands in the game, including a sold out and sweaty show at Auckland’s Neck of the Woods. Since then, the band have been plotting their next move in world domination, dropping fan favourite single Cowbella in June, and this week lifting the lid on Some Like It Hot with accompanying tune Fundraiser - with a video featuring Matt “Super Hans” King. The London based band, built around the core of Nina Cristante, Jezmi Tarik Fehmi and Sam Fenton, may have looked to be hiding out this year while cooking up this new batch of tunes, but in reality they’ve been anything but dormant. Cristante teamed up with Yves Tumor for a dangerously good duet on We Don’t Count, while Jezmi and Sam dropped another full-length album under their Double Virgo moniker just last month. With the album dropping on Matador this October, local fans will have a couple of short months to learn the words and get ready to scream and swoon along when bar italia hit our shores this December. Shit yeah! Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Every year, The Hollywood hosts a 24-hour movie marathon with a quirky line-up of movies. Take an immersive journey through the stunning habitats of Te Wao Nui inspiring every visitor to be kaitiaki (guardians) of our unique wildlife and wild places. Discover the rare and fascinating animals such as iconic kiwi and tuatara that are found nowhere else in the world. Learn about our native plant species and the importance of them in Māori culture, and the environment. Te Wao Nui offers both locals and tourists a truly unique experience of New Zealand’s animals, plants and culture all in one location at Auckland Zoo. Encompassing one fifth of the Zoo, is home to over 100 native plant species of Aotearoa and around 60 different animal species. is the first solo exhibition in Aotearoa New Zealand of Louise Bourgeois (1911–2010), one of the most intriguing and influential artists of the last century. The exhibition brings together a selection of works from an international private collection, exhibited publicly for the first time. The exhibition spans over six decades of Bourgeois’s career, from early paintings made in 1945 to a fabric work from the final year of her life. Widely celebrated for her psychologically charged and bold sculptural practice, Bourgeois explored themes of memory, family, the body and the subconscious, often drawing from personal experiences. She is best known for her series of large spider sculptures, which have been installed in many major international cities. offers an intimate encounter with Bourgeois’s work, and follows the evolution of her art practice over time. Highlights include paintings and her first series of sculptures, the , from the 1940s and early ‘50s; sculptures from the early 1960s; and significant later works, such as textile-based sculptures and sculptural enclosures. (2002) is a wall-mounted example of her internationally acclaimed series of spider sculptures, which she began in the mid-1990s. Also featured is her extraordinary hanging sculpture, , and late outdoor piece, . is proudly supported by the Contemporary Benefactors of Auckland Art Gallery. Auckland - we are back in 2026! The City of Sails will once again transform into the City of SailGP. description: Paco Peña is internationally acclaimed as the greatest living exponent of flamenco guitar. View times For over five decades, he has transformed the way audiences across the globe experience this most passionate of art forms. To see him perform is to witness flamenco at its purest—alive, uncompromising, and utterly captivating. Rooted in the culture of Andalucía, flamenco blends centuries of song, dance, and rhythm into a powerful expression of human emotion—grief and joy, struggle and celebration, passion and hope. In Peña’s hands, it becomes both profoundly Spanish and universally moving, resonating with audiences whether or not they know its traditions. Each concert begins with Peña’s spellbinding solo guitar and expands into a full flamenco experience with singers, dancers, and musicians, igniting the stage with fire, virtuosity, and soul. More than a performance, is an invitation to feel the heartbeat of Andalucía. Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Learn about the colourful history of this iconic venue on an Auckland Town Hall Tour. Visit aucklandlive.com for tour dates and details. Te huarahi ki reira Auckland Town Hall is opposite Aotea Square on Queen Street. This is along a main bus route and takes about 17-20 minutes to walk from Britomart Station and the ferry terminal. For parking options visit Auckland Transport’s website.

description: It’s nearly that time again, when Franklin Road puts on its festive best to share a little Christmas magic with tamariki, families, and anyone who loves the festive season. View times What makes the Franklin Road Christmas Lights special? It’s simply, local households decorating their homes for the joy of it. Every fairy light, inflatable reindeer, twinkling star, and quirky Christmas scene is dreamed up and created by the people who live right here. It’s a community tradition that’s been lovingly built, house by house, for more than 30 years. “We do it because seeing kids’ faces light up is the best gift we could ask for.” Once again, a huge shout-out goes to our amazing local Ponsonby businesses, who have chipped in to help light up some of our iconic Franklin Road trees. Their support means even more sparkle overhead as you wander down the street and with Ponsonby Road just around the corner, it’s easy to top off the night with a cocktail, dinner, or a sweet treat. Do note that on Wednesday 17 December & Thursday 18 December, there will be a spectacular Christmas Light Show at Te Rimutahi (254 Ponsonby Road) from 8.30pm – 10.30pm. To help keep the magic merry and bright, we ask visitors to: Te wāhi Franklin Road Xmas Lights Display He pārongo atu anō

Celebrate the magic of the season at the Downtown Christmas Market — a festive fusion of the much-loved General Collective and Britomart Saturday Market, uniting for one spectacular Christmas shopping experience in the heart of the city. View times Wander through Te Komititanga and Takutai Square, where you’ll find a vibrant mix of beautifully curated stalls brimming with handcrafted gifts, summer fashion, homewares, art, toys, and gourmet treats — all made with love by talented local creators. Feel the spirit of the season come alive beneath the giant Christmas tree — surrounded by festive market stalls, delicious bites, and the joyful buzz of Christmas in the city. ✨ Whether you’re searching for the perfect gift or simply soaking up the atmosphere, it’s the perfect way to celebrate a merry day out. Downtown Christmas Market | Saturday 13 December 2025 - Takutai Square | Britomart Saturday Market: 8.00am – 3.00pm - Te Komititanga | General Collective : 10.00am – 3.00pm Just a short stroll away, Queens Wharf will be buzzing with a Kids Christmas DIY activation — perfect for little makers to get creative and add their own handmade touch to the festive fun. Make a day of it — shop local, grab lunch, and enjoy the Christmas magic in the heart of the city. Brought to you by the Auckland Council whānau and the city centre targeted rate. ✨ See you there for a day of festive fun, local love, and family joy! description: A curly tale for tamariki! A fabulous show for littlies (and their parents and grandparents!). View times Dazzlehands, the award-winning story of the persuasive pig who won’t take no for an answer, by Wellington author and illustrator Sacha Cotter and Josh Morgan, is a hot favourite with young audiences, on the mat at pre-school and as a much-requested bedtime story. Now, RNZB Principal Joshua Guillemot-Rodgerson and Education and Community Engagement Manager Lauren Byrne are thrilled to have turned Dazzlehands into a moving and grooving ballet bash for six performers plus narration, with enchanting original music by William Phillipson and laugh-out-loud character costumes by Victoria Gridley. Experience the thrill of Auckland FC taking on Wellington Phoenix! Join us at Go Media Stadium for a high-energy derby you won't want to miss! View times Get ready for an electric Derby Day as Auckland FC takes on Wellington Phoenix at Go Media Stadium on 6 December 2025. This fierce rivalry always delivers high-energy action and an atmosphere that captures the heart of Kiwi football culture. The stadium is easy to reach by bus or train, with a short walk from Penrose Station, just plan ahead for limited event services. Rain or shine, the match goes ahead, so pack a poncho and secure your tickets through Ticketmaster, the official seller. Kids under two enter free on an adult’s lap, and you can grab merch near Gates A & D to top off the experience. Be part of the excitement and join Auckland for an unforgettable derby. Global alt-pop icon Lorde will bring her highly anticipated Ultrasound World Tour to her home country New Zealand in February 2026! View times The tour kicks off at Spark Arena, Auckland on Wednesday 11 February, marking Lorde’s first New Zealand show since 2023’s Solar Power Tour. Lorde’s critically acclaimed fourth studio album Virgin (out now via Universal Music New Zealand) has just made a triumphant return to #1 on the Aotearoa Music Charts, the Official Albums Chart (UK), and debuted at #2 on the Billboard 200 (US). Co-produced by Lorde, Jim-E Stack, and Dan Nigro, Virgin represents a bold sonic evolution—balancing maximalist production with her signature lyrical intimacy across 11 tracks. The album features fan favourites including “What Was That”, “Man of the Year”, “Hammer”, “Favourite Daughter”, and “Shapeshifter”. description: Enjoy over 150 original artworks, prints, and installations by the elusive street artist. This is your final chance to experience Banksy’s most iconic pieces in New Zealand. Te Pae Christchurch Convention Centre The world-famous exhibition, The Art of Banksy, is coming to Christchurch this summer at Te Pae Christchurch Convention Centre. With over 150 original artworks, prints, and installations by the elusive street artist, this is your final chance to experience Banksy’s most iconic and thought-provoking pieces in Aotearoa NZ. title: Supercars Christchurch Super 440
description: Ōtautahi Christchurch is geared up to welcome the Repco Supercars Championship to Ruapuna Motorsport Park. Ruapuna Motorsport Park, Christchurch As Australasia’s premier touring car series, Supercars promises high-octane action, fierce competition and an unforgettable experience — and we can’t wait to see it all unfold right here in Christchurch in 2026. For the first time, drivers will battle it out on the iconic South Island circuit — led by Kiwi star Matt Payne, winner of the Jason Richards Memorial Trophy and now Bathurst 1000 champion. Fans from across Aotearoa can rally trackside to cheer on their 'King of the Mountain. ' Multiple transport options will be available to make getting to Ruapuna Raceway easy and hassle-free over the event weekend. . As Christchurch prepares to host Supercars, Ruapuna Raceway is undergoing targeted upgrades to meet track safety standards for its inaugural year. Led by the Canterbury Car Club and supported by Christchurch City Council, ChristchurchNZ, and Supercars, the immediate focus is on ensuring the circuit complies with all safety requirements for drivers and spectators. Infrastructure enhancements will continue in subsequent years, building on this foundation to elevate the venue into a world-class motorsport destination. An accessible viewing area will be located between turn 10 and turn 11, near gate B. Please purchase a Trackside General Admission ticket and email to advise your requirements. The venue is a mix of sealed roads, dirt roads and grass. Viewing areas around the track are all raised above the racetrack, and therefore, there is a requirement to navigate inclines and descents around the venue. Corporate tickets can be purchased for the Engine Room, which caters to those using a wheelchair. There are also a number of wheelchair-friendly toilets in the precinct. Accessible parking will be located in the premium carpark. There are limited carparks in this location, which will be on a first-come, first-served basis. Spectators parking here will need to show a valid ticket to the event (including all passengers in the vehicle) and a valid NZ mobility parking permit clearly displayed on the front windscreen of the vehicle. Entry to this carpark for valid mobility car parking permits is free. If the carpark is full, patrons can head to the public carpark or to the park n ride at the Canterbury Agricultural Park (A&P showgrounds, 102 Curletts Road, Sockburn, Christchurch). Accessible buses will be operating throughout the day. Check back here for updates as more action unfolds in the lead-up to . Event starts in What's On
price: A 'Super shuttle service' will be running from the central city. This is a paid morning and nightly service, and return shuttle tickets can be purchased starting from $30.

description: Get amongst the fun this summer as the World Buskers Festival returns to Ōtautahi Christchurch for ten days of street performance, ticketed shows, and pop-up surprises across the city. Multiple venues across the city This summer the streets of Ōtautahi Christchurch come alive with laughter, spectacle, and the kind of unexpected moments that make the World Buskers Festival one of our most loved festivals. From Friday, 23 January to Sunday, 1 February 2026, across the five city pitches and two pop-up locations, the festival blends the best of international street talent with the creativity and spirit of homegrown performers. Expect jaw-dropping acrobatics, cheeky comedy, world-class circus acts, and unforgettable moments in every corner of the central city.
